Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: How do individuals create strong, enduring interpersonal relationships? Given that positive social ties predict health and longevity, it is critical to understand how we initiate, form and maintain these vital interpersonal connections. This research will test one important component of this question: what psychological and biological factors predict whether one chooses to initiate a friendship or romantic relationship with another? James Roney (University of California, Santa Barbara) will examine the psychobiology of relationship formation, testing whether changes in hormones during an initial social encounter predict whether someone wants to begin a relationship with a partner. The PI will experimentally manipulate feelings of closeness in initial social encounters with others, and will measure hormone changes in response to this interaction. He will also test their desire to initiate romantic or friendship-based relationships with their partners. This will allow a test of whether hormone responses when interacting with a potential relationship partner act as a "chemical code" that predicts partner choice and relationship pursuit. The studies will measure changes in testosterone and estrogen (sex hormones implicated in human mating psychology), cortisol (a hormone that mobilizes energy availability), and oxytocin (a hormone implicated in social bonding); data analyses will also test the extent to which these hormone changes predict desire for relationship initiation. Achievement of these objectives will advance our basic understanding of the biological signals implicated in human social encounters. In addition, enhanced understanding of the endocrine mechanisms involved in human social interactions may help identify physiological signatures of social disorders. For example, individuals with social anxiety or high loneliness may have atypical hormone responses to social interactions, but knowledge of the typical physiological responses found in people without such conditions is necessary to test such possibilities. Thus, in addition to advancing basic science, this research holds the potential to construct typical baselines against which atypical responses could be detected.

POR.DRECONTENT:
What is the internal “chemistry” of human attraction that helps to drive relationship formation? This project tested hormone responses to initial social interactions to test which combination of rapid hormone changes would best predict romantic or friendship-based attraction to others. In addition, the studies manipulated feelings of closeness in conversations to assess whether greater closeness would predict both stronger attraction and larger hormone responses as markers of that attraction. Nearly 1000 individuals participated in a series of studies that collected over 6000 hormone measurements.

A number of clear patterns have emerged from the research. First, interactions with potential mates trigger rapid increases in cortisol that are absent after same-sex interactions that have similar conversation content. Cortisol increases were often very large in opposite-sex interactions, but were absent on average among participants in relationships, suggesting that they are sensitive to the likelihood of mate pursuit. Results were more mixed for the effects of feelings of closeness. In one experiment, participants took part in a validated closeness induction procedure in which conversation questions were more intimate in one condition than in the other. This manipulation had no effects on feelings of romantic attraction, however, and also no effects on any hormone responses. In a follow-up experiment, we made the closeness differences larger by using the high closeness induction questions in one group but having participants complete puzzles in the same room together but without conversing in the other group. In this case, mate attraction was stronger in the closeness group, and cortisol also increased in that group but not in the puzzles group. That result supports a role for feelings of closeness in inducing hormone responses, if differences in such feelings are large enough.

In terms of which hormone responses best predict mate attractiveness, there were intriguing findings. For men, across studies, when participants indicated stronger attraction to a potential mate, they also tended to show larger increases in cortisol. That same result occurred less consistently for women. For women, two separate studies found that women who reported stronger attraction to potential mates also tended to show larger increases in oxytocin – a hormone that has been implicated in social bonding. Changes in the gonadal hormones testosterone and estradiol were not consistently associated with mate attractiveness judgments. The hormonal predictors of opposite-sex friendship ratings were very similar to the predictors of mate attractiveness ratings, but no hormone variables appeared to predict same-sex friend judgments.

These findings may make scientific impacts by improving our basic understanding of the roles of hormone variables in human partner choice. They suggest a possible shift in emphasis away from gonadal hormones like testosterone and estradiol and instead toward further investigation of the roles of cortisol and oxytocin.

This project had broader impacts from its training opportunities and relevance for more applied disciplines. Two graduate students received extensive training throughout much of their graduate careers through their close involvement in all phases of the research, and approximately 15-20 undergraduate research assistants per year of the project gained experience in the research process through their valuable contributions. The discovery of hormonal predictors of attraction may help guide more applied research by establishing baselines for typical functioning that can be compared to the hormone responses from individuals with social anxiety or other conditions that may impair the establishment of important social relationships.
